required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Bare Metal Stents and Drug Eluting Stents in Patients Who Underwent Blood Transfusion
clinical_study.official_title: Bare-metal Stents(BMS) Versus Drug-eluting Stents(DES) in Patients Who Underwent Periprocedural Blood Transfusion : A Nationwide Longitudinal Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Retrospective cohort study of Korean National Healthcare Insurance Database. To investigate clinical outcomes of bare metal stents versus drug eluting stents in patients who underwent periprocedural red blood cell transfusion.

detailed_description.textblock:
A Korean nationwide, multi-center, retrospective observational cohort study.
The receipt of red blood cell transfusion is at high risk of cardiac events or death. But little is know regarding the comparative outcomes of BMS and DES implantation in patients who underwent periprocedural red blood cell transfusion.
Longitudinal data is collected from administrative claims in the national health insurance services of Korea. All Korean data(N=500,591) undergoing PCI from 2006 to 2015 is extracted. BMS or DES Patients(N=28,322) who received periprocedural red blood cell transfusion is investigate. Clinical outcomes until December 31, 2017 is investigate.
Primary endpoint is a time to the first major adverse clinical event(MACE) defined as a composite of all-cause death, revascularization, critically ill cardiovascular status, or stroke.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence density of MACE (Major adverse clinical events)
primary_outcome.description: The first major adverse clinical event(MACE) defined as a composite of all-cause death, revascularization, critically ill cardiovascular status, and stroke.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence density of MACE (Major adverse clinical events)
primary_outcome.description: The first major adverse clinical event(MACE) defined as a composite of all-cause death, revascularization, critically ill cardiovascular status, and stroke.

intervention.description: BMS (Bare Metal Stent) and DES (drug-eluting stent) transplants with periprocedural red blood cell transfusion

study_pop.textblock: All Korean patients undergoing BMS or DES implantation from January 1, 2005 to December 31, 2016 who received periprocedural red blood cell transfusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with percutaneous coronary intervention from 2006 to 2015
- Patients with the implantation of BMS or DES
- Patients with the receipt of periprocedural red blood cell transfusion
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients without any of stent implantation
